At 21:13 20/08/2004, you wrote:
>Karl,
>
>I wanted to follow on a bit on what Colin said.  I agree Colin's
>method might help but I want to just point out what might be going
>on.  You seem to have run into a classic local optimum.  It's
>probably a situation where it's very easy to get some of the
>classifications right using some rough heuristic which is found
>early on, but then to get any of the other classifications right
>requires *sacrificing* the naive function that was found first,
>which is almost never going to happen since it means dropping in
>fitness for a while.  The presence of species should help with this
>problem but the basin around the initial poor solution may be so
>large that it's virtually inevitable to get pulled in.
>
>This kind of thing seems to happen more in classification problems
>than control problems (just based on my observations, not
>experimental backup).

I'd think that it was just as likely (a local optimum, that is) in any 
problem.  But that only for relatively simple problems do we have any 
chance of visualizing it well-enough to be able to confirm what's going on.

For example, suppose you were evolving networks which play a game.  Then 
you might well see similar progress, improving so far, stalling for a 
while, improving some more, stalling again...  Which I would interpret as 
passage through a series of local minima.  However, when the system comes 
to rest, you might find you have a population of controllers which all 
employ the same large-scale strategy.  E.g. maybe they are all 
defensive.  From an ESS (Evolutionary Stable Strategy) point of view this 
population is unstable w.r.t invasion by other strategies (e.g. ones which 
exploit the weaknesses in defensive play) but because the population has 
got stuck in the "defensive" local optimum it cannot readily progress.

The "defensive" local minimum might, however, be a very wide optimum.  e.g. 
all the landscape for miles may slope upwards towards this mountain, and 
there may be a large grouping of sub-peaks within the "defensive" mountain 
range (representing different but related strategies).  Other (possibly 
higher) peaks do exist on the landscape, but they are a long way away.  You 
can't get there from here.

So, to get to the point, in this case calling the defensive optimum "local" 
does not really do it justice.  It's more a "regional" optimum because 
anything better is a very (very, _very_) long way away.  And, if 
"defensive" were some less intuitive strategy, then user might well fail to 
realize that there could be alternatives out there.  Thus he might deduce 
that the run had arrived at the "global" optimum (dwelling temporarily in a 
few "local" optima along the way).

--

This question of the shape and size of fitness landscapes is one that has 
intrigued me for years.  I have a few intuitions about them which you might 
like to argue with:

1) They're big.  And for any really interesting question (like how to play 
chess) they're not big like the universe is big, they're _much_ larger than 
that.

2) Their shape is determined by the fitness function (obviously) but also, 
(less obvious) by the set of mutations used.  The set of mutations affects 
the connectivity of the landscape.  Addition of a new mutation can pull 
distant points into adjacency.

3) Increased connectivity pulls points closer together and speeds evolution.

4) Increased connectivity increases the size of "neighborhood" around each 
point, and slows evolution.

5) So there's a trade-off between 3 and 4, which is problem dependent and 
nobody knows how to estimate the best compromise.

6) In any problem where the axes of the fitness landscape are not totally 
interdependent (almost any problem) there will be local optima.

7) for most complex problems, optima cluster together in groups.  I like to 
call these meta-optima.  The reason for this is, if the problem is 
subdividable (modularisable) then each sub-set of the problem can be solved 
in a variety of ways, each with a different (partial) fitness.  The 
presence of multiple solutions for each module has the effect of putting 
sub-peaks on the side of each principle optimum.

         Anyway, enough back-of-napkin rambling.  Point 7, in particular, 
shows how simulated-annealing type approaches work...  Point 5, I feel has 
a lot to say about the efficiency of various TWEANN and GP approaches, but 
not enough to prompt concrete conclusions yet :-(.

         Again this brings home to me that any evolving software technique 
really needs functional, automatic modularity before it has any hope of 
breaking into the BIG problems.  Modularity entails a trade off very like 
(5) in that the presence of modularity increases the size of the overall 
search space (adding choices about how to define modules) but hugely 
decreases the size of the parts that are considered at one time (e.g. each 
modules fitness landscape is much, much smaller than the overall fitness 
landscape.).

         Ian Badcoe
